gpt-message.content: You are an expert in hardware design with a deep understanding of Verilog RTL codes. Now I want to train a large language model for code comment generation tasks specifically focused on Verilog RTL codes. And I want you to help me process the raw data, transforming it into suitable formats that can serve as inputs and outputs for the model.

Name of the module and its functionality is as follows: 
Module name: lfsr_race.
Explanation: This Verilog module describes a 15-bit linear feedback shift register (LFSR). The LFSR is initialized with a value of 25, and at each clock cycle, if the 'enable' signal is high, it advances the state based on a feedback function. The feedback function implemented here is an XOR of the 14th, 10th, 6th, and 1st bit of the shifter register. The current state of the LFSR is available on the 'out' port.

Input and output ports and their explanation is as follows: 
Input ports: clock, enable. 
Explanation: The 'clock' port is the clock signal used to time the progression of the shift register. Whenever there is a positive edge on this signal, the shift register will move to the next state, provided the 'enable' signal is high. The 'enable' port is a control signal. When 'enable' is high (1), the shift register state updates; when 'enable' is low (0), the state of the shift register remains the same.

Output ports: out. 
Explanation: The 'out' port provides the current state of the shift register 'sreg'. This 15-bit signal provides insight into the internal state of the module and can be used by other modules in the larger system.

Internal signals and their explanation is as follows: 
Internal signals: sreg.
Explanation: 'sreg' is a 15-bit register signal which serves as a state holder for our linear feedback shift register. Its initial value is set to 14'd25 (decimal 25). On each positive edge of the clock signal, if 'enable' is high, the register state advances based on a feedback function - an XOR of bits 14, 10, 6, and 1 of the shift register. The current state of 'sreg' is available on the 'out' port.
